qas.question: What percent of the Chilean population were indigenous according to the 2002 census?
What is the name for the Polynesian people living on Easter Island?
Who are many of the people of Chile the descendants of?
How long were the Mapuche able to fight off the Spaniards?
When did the Mapuche surrender to the Chilean army?

context: According to the 2002 Census, <a0_0>4.6%<a0_0/> of the Chilean population, including <a1_0>the Rapanui<a1_0/> (a Polynesian people) of Easter Island, was indigenous, although most show varying degrees of mixed heritage. Many are descendants of <a2_0>the Mapuche<a2_0/>, and live in Santiago, Araucanía and the lake district. The Mapuche successfully fought off defeat in the first 300–<a3_0>350 years<a3_0/> of Spanish rule during the Arauco War. Relations with the new Chilean Republic were good until the Chilean state decided to occupy their lands. During the Occupation of Araucanía the Mapuche surrendered to the country's army in the <a4_0>1880s<a4_0/>. Their land was opened to settlement by Chileans and Europeans. Conflict over Mapuche land rights continues to the present.
